title: Small Grains, Big Nutrition
title_page: Small Grains, Big Nutrition - The New York Times
text:
Photo
Small grains can pack a big nutritional punch, writes the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman, who this week continued her exploration into cooking with grains. She writes:
This week I worked with tiny grains and seeds: millet and teff, amaranth and chia seeds. These can be challenging, and I had a few starts and stops along the way until I came up with a collection of recipes I was pleased with, including some delicious, moist savory pancakes made with beet greens and cooked amaranth. I continued working with chia seeds; this time I didn’t soak them, and added them to whole-grain muffins and pancakes. That’s how I used to use chia seeds way back when, before they disappeared for a few decades from the whole-foods scene. You can raise the nutritional content of your whole-grain pastries and breads just by adding 3 or 4 tablespoons; along with their considerable nutrients, the seeds contribute interesting texture like that of poppy seeds. You might have only begun to see teff in the bins of whole-foods stores. These teensy little grains have a lot going for them nutritionally. Teff is higher in calcium than any other grain, and is also high in vitamin C. It contains no gluten. The grain has always been a staple in Ethiopia, where teff flour used to make a spongy flatbread called injera, whose nutritional benefits are a function of both the bacilli in the fermented batter it’s made with and the nutrients in the grain itself. I tried several different recipes for injera this week, but could not succeed in making something I liked. I did, however, make some good buttermilk pancakes using teff flour. Millet isn’t quite as tiny as teff or amaranth, but it is quite small, like quinoa. It’s a good source of manganese, phosphorus, magnesium and tryptophan, as well as B vitamins, calcium, potassium and zinc. It’s gluten-free, and I like to use the flour I make by grinding millet in a spice mill to enrich whole-grain breads and pastries.
Here are five recipes for cooking with small grains.
Photo
Amaranth, Ricotta and Greens Pancakes: Cooked amaranth works well in baked goods and griddled cakes because it’s so moist.
Photo
Bran and Chia Muffins: These moist, hearty muffins have great texture because of the slight crunch that the chia seeds contribute.
Photo
Millet and Greens Gratin: Millet can be dry, but here there’s lots of custard to moisten it, and it works really nicely to hold this gratin together.
Photo
Teff Pancakes With Chia, Millet and Blueberries: If you’re trying to work more grains and seeds into your diet, a pancake can be a good home for them.
Photo
Oven-Baked Millet: Serving millet as you would a polenta makes perfect sense.
